column2: KETCH'S EVENING VISIT.
column3: KETCH'S EVENING VISIT.

column2: It were surely a breach of politeness on our part not to attend Mr. Ketch in his impromptu evening visit!
column3: It were surely a breach of politeness on our part not to attend mr Ketch in his impromptu evening visit!

column2: He shuffled along at the very top of his speed, his mouth watering, while the delicious odour of tripe and onions appeared to be borne on the air to his olfactory nerves: so strong is the force of fancy.
column3: He shuffled along at the very top of his speed, his mouth watering, while the delicious odour of tripe and onions appeared to be borne on the air to his olfactory nerves: so strong is the force of fancy.

column2: Arrived at his destination, he found the shop closed.
column3: Arrived at his destination, he found the shop closed.

column2: Mr. Ketch seized the knocker on the shop-door--there was no other entrance to the house--and brought it down with a force that shook the first-floor sitting-room, and startled Mr. Harper, the lay clerk, almost out of his armchair, as he sat before the fire.
column3: mr Ketch seized the knocker on the shop door-there was no other entrance to the house-and brought it down with a force that shook the first floor sitting room, and startled mr Harper, the lay clerk, almost out of his armchair, as he sat before the fire.

column2: Be I in time? demanded Ketch, his voice shaking.
column3: Be I in time? demanded Ketch, his voice shaking.

column2: In time for what? responded the girl.
column3: In time for what? responded the girl.

column2: Why, for supper, said Ketch, penetrating into the shop, which was lighted by a candle that stood on the counter, the one the girl had brought in her hand.
column3: Why, for supper, said Ketch, penetrating into the shop, which was lighted by a candle that stood on the counter, the one the girl had brought in her hand.

column2: Old Jenkins ain't here, said she.
column3: Old Jenkins ain't here, said she.

column2: You had better go into the parlour, if you're come to supper.
column3: You had better go into the parlour, if you're come to supper.

column2: Ketch went down the shop, sniffing curiously.
column3: Ketch went down the shop, sniffing curiously.

column2: Sharp as fancy is, he could not say that he was regaled with the scent of onions, but he supposed the saucepan lid might be on.
column3: Sharp as fancy is, he could not say that he was regaled with the scent of onions, but he supposed the saucepan lid might be on.

column2: Ketch entered the parlour, and sat down.
column3: Ketch entered the parlour, and sat down.

column2: There was a fire in the grate, but no light, and there were not, so far as Ketch could see, any preparations yet for the entertainment.
column3: There was a fire in the grate, but no light, and there were not, so far as Ketch could see, any preparations yet for the entertainment.

column2: They're going to have it downstairs in the kitchen, soliloquized he.
column3: They're going to have it downstairs in the kitchen, soliloquized he.

column2: And that's a sight more comfortabler.	And that's a sight more comfortabler.
She's gone out to fetch it, I shouldn't wonder!" he continued, alluding to Mrs. Jenkins, and sniffing again strongly, but without result.
column3: She's gone out to fetch it, I shouldn't wonder!" he continued, alluding to mrs Jenkins, and sniffing again strongly, but without result.

column2: That's right! she won't let 'em serve her with short onions, she won't; she has a tongue of her own.	That's right! she won't let 'em serve her with short onions, she won't; she has a tongue of her own.

Such a thing as a run on the delicacy had occurred more than once, to Ketch's certain knowledge, and tardy customers had been sent away disappointed, to wait in longing anticipations for the next tripe night.
column3: Such a thing as a run on the delicacy had occurred more than once, to Ketch's certain knowledge, and tardy customers had been sent away disappointed, to wait in longing anticipations for the next tripe night.

column2: He went into a cold perspiration at the bare idea.
column3: He went into a cold perspiration at the bare idea.

column2: And where was old Jenkins, all this time, that he had not come in?
column3: And where was old Jenkins, all this time, that he had not come in?

column2: And where was Joe?
column3: And where was Joe?

column2: A pretty thing to invite a gentleman out to an impromptu supper, and serve him in this way!
column3: A pretty thing to invite a gentleman out to an impromptu supper, and serve him in this way!

column2: What could they mean by it?
column3: What could they mean by it?

column2: He groped his way round the corner of the shop to where lay the kitchen stairs, whose position he pretty well knew, and called.
column3: He groped his way round the corner of the shop to where lay the kitchen stairs, whose position he pretty well knew, and called.

column2: Here, Sally, Betty--whatever your name is--ain't there nobody at home?
column3: Here, Sally, Betty-whatever your name is-ain't there nobody at home?

column2: The girl heard, and came forth, the same candle in hand.
column3: The girl heard, and came forth, the same candle in hand.

column2: Who be you calling to, I'd like to know?	Who be you calling to, I'd like to know?
My name's Lidyar, if you please."
column3: My name's Lidyar, if you please."

column2: Gone out for what tripe? asked the girl.
column3: Gone out for what tripe? asked the girl.

column2: What be you talking of?
column3: What be you talking of?

column2: The tripe for supper, said Ketch.
column3: The tripe for supper, said Ketch.

column2: There ain't no tripe for supper, replied she.
column3: There ain't no tripe for supper, replied she.

column2: There is tripe for supper, persisted Ketch.
column3: There is tripe for supper, persisted Ketch.

column2: And me and old Jenkins are going to have some of it.	And me and old Jenkins are going to have some of it.
There's tripe and onions."
column3: There's tripe and onions."

column2: The girl shook her head.
column3: The girl shook her head.

column2: I dun know nothing about it.	I dun know nothing about it.
Missis is upstairs, fixing the mustard."
column3: Missis is upstairs, fixing the mustard."

column2: Oh come! this gave a promise of something.
column3: Oh come! this gave a promise of something.

column2: Old Ketch thought mustard the greatest condiment that tripe could be accompanied by, in conjunction with onions.
column3: Old Ketch thought mustard the greatest condiment that tripe could be accompanied by, in conjunction with onions.

column2: But she must have been a long time "fixing" the mustard; whatever that might mean.
column3: But she must have been a long time "fixing" the mustard; whatever that might mean.

column2: His spirits dropped again, and he grew rather exasperated.
column3: His spirits dropped again, and he grew rather exasperated.

column2: Go up and ask your missis how long I be to wait? he growled.
column3: Go up and ask your missis how long I be to wait? he growled.

column2: The girl, possibly feeling a little curiosity herself, came up with her candle.
column3: The girl, possibly feeling a little curiosity herself, came up with her candle.

column2: He's gone to bed, and missis is putting him a plaster on his chest.
column3: He's gone to bed, and missis is putting him a plaster on his chest.

column2: The words fell as ice on old Ketch.
column3: The words fell as ice on old Ketch.

column2: A mustard-plaster? shrieked he.
column3: A mustard plaster? shrieked he.

column2: What else but a mustard-plaster! she retorted.
column3: What else but a mustard plaster! she retorted.

column2: Did you think it was a pitch?	Did you think it was a pitch?
There's a fire lighted in his room, and she's making it there."
column3: There's a fire lighted in his room, and she's making it there."

column2: Nothing more certain.
column3: Nothing more certain.

column2: Poor Jenkins, who had coughed more than usual the last two days, perhaps from the wet weather, and whose chest in consequence was very painful, had been ordered to bed this night by his wife when tea was over.
column3: Poor Jenkins, who had coughed more than usual the last two days, perhaps from the wet weather, and whose chest in consequence was very painful, had been ordered to bed this night by his wife when tea was over.

column2: She had gone up herself, as soon as her shop was shut, to administer a mustard-plaster.
column3: She had gone up herself, as soon as her shop was shut, to administer a mustard plaster.

column2: Ketch was quite stunned with uncertainty.
column3: Ketch was quite stunned with uncertainty.

column2: A man in bed, with a plaster on his chest, was not likely to invite company to supper.
column3: A man in bed, with a plaster on his chest, was not likely to invite company to supper.

column2: Before he had seen his way out of the shock, or the girl had done staring at him, Mrs. Jenkins descended the stairs and joined them, having been attracted by the conversation.
column3: Before he had seen his way out of the shock, or the girl had done staring at him, mrs Jenkins descended the stairs and joined them, having been attracted by the conversation.

column2: He says he's come to supper: tripe and onions, said the girl, unceremoniously introducing Mr. Ketch and the subject to her wondering mistress.
column3: He says he's come to supper: tripe and onions, said the girl, unceremoniously introducing mr Ketch and the subject to her wondering mistress.

column2: Mrs. Jenkins, not much more famous for meekness in expressing her opinions than was Ketch, turned her gaze upon that gentleman.
column3: mrs Jenkins, not much more famous for meekness in expressing her opinions than was Ketch, turned her gaze upon that gentleman.

column2: Why, I have come for supper, that's what I have come for, shrieked Ketch, trembling.
column3: Why, I have come for supper, that's what I have come for, shrieked Ketch, trembling.

column2: Jenkins invited me to supper; tripe and onions; and I'd like to know what it all means, and where the supper is.
column3: Jenkins invited me to supper; tripe and onions; and I'd like to know what it all means, and where the supper is.

column2: You are going into your dotage, said Mrs. Jenkins, with an amount of scorn so great that it exasperated Ketch as much as the words themselves.
column3: You are going into your dotage, said mrs Jenkins, with an amount of scorn so great that it exasperated Ketch as much as the words themselves.

column2: You'll be wanting a lunatic asylum next.	You'll be wanting a lunatic asylum next.
Tripe and onions! If Jenkins was to hint at such a thing as a plate of tripe coming inside my house, I'd tripe him.
column3: Tripe and onions! If Jenkins was to hint at such a thing as a plate of tripe coming inside my house, I'd tripe him.

column2: Is this the way to treat a man? foamed Ketch, disappointment and hunger driving him almost into the state hinted at by Mrs. Jenkins.
column3: Is this the way to treat a man? foamed Ketch, disappointment and hunger driving him almost into the state hinted at by mrs Jenkins.

column2: Joe Jenkins sends me down a note an hour ago, to come here to supper with his old father, and it was to be tripe and onions!	Joe Jenkins sends me down a note an hour ago, to come here to supper with his old father, and it was to be tripe and onions!
Here, Lydia, open the door and let him out, cried Mrs. Jenkins, waving her hand imperatively towards it.
column3: Here, Lydia, open the door and let him out, cried mrs Jenkins, waving her hand imperatively towards it.

column2: And what have you been at with your face again? continued she, as the candle held by that damsel reflected its light.
column3: And what have you been at with your face again? continued she, as the candle held by that damsel reflected its light.

column2: One can't see it for colly.	One can't see it for colly.
If I do put you into that mask I have threatened, you won't like it, girl.
column3: If I do put you into that mask I have threatened, you won't like it, girl.

column2: Hold your tongue, old Ketch, or I'll call Mr. Harper down to you.
column3: Hold your tongue, old Ketch, or I'll call mr Harper down to you.

column2: Write a note!
column3: Write a note!

column2: What else?
column3: What else?

column2: He has wrote no note; he has been too suffering the last few hours to think of notes, or of you either.
column3: He has wrote no note; he has been too suffering the last few hours to think of notes, or of you either.

column2: I shall be drove one, sobbed Ketch.
column3: I shall be drove one, sobbed Ketch.

column2: I was promised a treat of--
column3: I was promised a treat of-

column2: There!
column3: There!

column2: Take yourself off.
column3: Take yourself off.

column2: My goodness, me! disturbing my house with such a crazy errand!" And, taking old Ketch by the shoulders, who was rather feeble and tottering, from lumbago and age, Mrs. Jenkins politely marshalled him outside, and closed the door upon him.
column3: My goodness, me! disturbing my house with such a crazy errand!" And, taking old Ketch by the shoulders, who was rather feeble and tottering, from lumbago and age, mrs Jenkins politely marshalled him outside, and closed the door upon him.

column2: Insolent old fellow! she exclaimed to her husband, to whom she went at once and related the occurrence.
column3: Insolent old fellow! she exclaimed to her husband, to whom she went at once and related the occurrence.

column2: I wonder what he'll pretend he has next from you?	I wonder what he'll pretend he has next from you?
A note of invitation, indeed!"
column3: A note of invitation, indeed!"

column2: My dear, said Jenkins, revolving the news, and speaking as well as his chest would allow him, "it must have been a trick played him by the young college gentlemen.
column3: My dear, said Jenkins, revolving the news, and speaking as well as his chest would allow him, "it must have been a trick played him by the young college gentlemen.

column2: We should not be too hard upon the poor old man.
column3: We should not be too hard upon the poor old man.

column2: He's not very agreeable or good-tempered, I'm afraid it must be allowed; but--I'd not have sent him away without a bit of supper, my dear."
column3: He's not very agreeable or good tempered, I'm afraid it must be allowed; but-I'd not have sent him away without a bit of supper, my dear."

column2: I dare say you'd not, retorted Mrs. Jenkins.
column3: I dare say you'd not, retorted mrs Jenkins.

column2: All the world knows you are soft enough for anything.	All the world knows you are soft enough for anything.
I have sent him away with a flea in his ear; that's what I have done."
column3: I have sent him away with a flea in his ear; that's what I have done."

column2: Mr. Ketch had at length come to the same conclusion: the invitation must be the work of the college gentlemen.
column3: mr Ketch had at length come to the same conclusion: the invitation must be the work of the college gentlemen.

column2: Deceived, betrayed, fainting for supper, done out of the delicious tripe and onions, he leaned against the shutters, and gave vent to a prolonged and piteous howl.
column3: Deceived, betrayed, fainting for supper, done out of the delicious tripe and onions, he leaned against the shutters, and gave vent to a prolonged and piteous howl.

column2: It might have drawn tears from a stone.
column3: It might have drawn tears from a stone.

column2: In a frame of mind that was not enviable, he turned his steps homeward, clasping his hands upon his empty stomach, and vowing the most intense vengeance upon the college boys.
column3: In a frame of mind that was not enviable, he turned his steps homeward, clasping his hands upon his empty stomach, and vowing the most intense vengeance upon the college boys.

column2: The occurrence naturally caused him to cast back his thoughts to that other trick-the locking him into the cloisters, in which Jenkins had been a fellow-victim--and he doubled his fists in impotent anger.
column3: The occurrence naturally caused him to cast back his thoughts to that other trick the locking him into the cloisters, in which Jenkins had been a fellow victim-and he doubled his fists in impotent anger.

column2: This comes of their not having been flogged for that! he groaned.
column3: This comes of their not having been flogged for that! he groaned.

column2: Engaged in these reflections of gall and bitterness, old Ketch gained his lodge, unlocked it, and entered.
column3: Engaged in these reflections of gall and bitterness, old Ketch gained his lodge, unlocked it, and entered.

column2: No wonder that he turned his eyes upon the cloister keys, the reminiscence being so strong within him.
column3: No wonder that he turned his eyes upon the cloister keys, the reminiscence being so strong within him.

column2: But, to say he turned his eyes upon the cloister keys, is a mere figure of speech.
column3: But, to say he turned his eyes upon the cloister keys, is a mere figure of speech.

column2: No keys were there.
column3: No keys were there.

column2: Ketch stood a statue transfixed, and stared as hard as the flickering blaze from his dying fire would allow him.
column3: Ketch stood a statue transfixed, and stared as hard as the flickering blaze from his dying fire would allow him.

column2: Seizing a match-box, he struck a light and held it to the hook.
column3: Seizing a match box, he struck a light and held it to the hook.

column2: Ketch was no conjuror, and it never occurred to him to suspect that the keys had been removed before his own departure.
column3: Ketch was no conjuror, and it never occurred to him to suspect that the keys had been removed before his own departure.

column2: How had them wicked ones got in? he foamed.
column3: How had them wicked ones got in? he foamed.

column2: Had they forced his winder?--had they took a skeleton key to his door?--had they come down the chimbley?	Had they forced his winder?--had they took a skeleton key to his door?--had they come down the chimbley?
He didn't think they'd mind a little fire.
column3: He didn't think they'd mind a little fire.

column2: It was that insolent Bywater!--or that young villain, Tod Yorke!--or that undaunted Tom Channing!--or perhaps all three leagued together!
column3: It was that insolent Bywater!--or that young villain, Tod Yorke!--or that undaunted Tom Channing!--or perhaps all three leagued together!

column2: He examined the window; he examined the door; he cast a glance up the chimney.
column3: He examined the window; he examined the door; he cast a glance up the chimney.

column2: Nothing, however, appeared to have been touched or disturbed, and there was no soot on the floor.
column3: Nothing, however, appeared to have been touched or disturbed, and there was no soot on the floor.

column2: Cutting himself a piece of bread and cheese, lamenting at its dryness, and eating it as he went along, he proceeded out again, locking up his lodge as before.
column3: Cutting himself a piece of bread and cheese, lamenting at its dryness, and eating it as he went along, he proceeded out again, locking up his lodge as before.

column2: There ain't a boy in the school but what'll come to be hung! danced old Ketch in his rage.
column3: There ain't a boy in the school but what'll come to be hung! danced old Ketch in his rage.

column2: He would have preferred not to find the keys; but to go to the head-master with a story of their theft.
column3: He would have preferred not to find the keys; but to go to the head master with a story of their theft.

column2: It was possible, it was just possible that, going, keys in hand, the master might refuse to believe his tale.
column3: It was possible, it was just possible that, going, keys in hand, the master might refuse to believe his tale.

column2: Away he hobbled, and arrived at the house of the head-master.
column3: Away he hobbled, and arrived at the house of the head master.

column2: The other masters lived at a distance, and Ketch's old legs were aching. What was he to do?
column3: The other masters lived at a distance, and Ketch's old legs were aching. What was he to do?

column2: Make his complaint to some one, he was determined upon.
column3: Make his complaint to some one, he was determined upon.

column2: The new senior, Huntley, lived too far off for his lumbago; so he turned his steps to the next senior's, Tom Channing, and demanded to see him.
column3: The new senior, Huntley, lived too far off for his lumbago; so he turned his steps to the next senior's, Tom Channing, and demanded to see him.

column2: Tom heard the story, which was given him in detail.
column3: Tom heard the story, which was given him in detail.

column2: He told Ketch--and with truth--that he knew nothing about it, but would make inquiries in the morning.
column3: He told Ketch-and with truth-that he knew nothing about it, but would make inquiries in the morning.

column2: Ketch was fain to depart, and Tom returned to the sitting-room, and threw himself into a chair in a burst of laughter.
column3: Ketch was fain to depart, and Tom returned to the sitting room, and threw himself into a chair in a burst of laughter.

column2: What is the matter? they asked.
column3: What is the matter? they asked.

column2: The primest lark, returned Tom.
column3: The primest lark, returned Tom.

column2: Some of the fellows have been sending Ketch an invitation to sup at Jenkins's off tripe and onions, and when he arrived there he found it was a hoax, and Mrs. Jenkins turned him out again.	Some of the fellows have been sending Ketch an invitation to sup at Jenkins's off tripe and onions, and when he arrived there he found it was a hoax, and mrs Jenkins turned him out again.
That's what Master Charley must have gone after."

column2: Hamish turned round.
column3: Hamish turned round.

column2: Gone after it, there's no doubt, replied Tom.
column3: Gone after it, there's no doubt, replied Tom.
